topicv3: Agricultural Risk and Security m1327607 1967,Agricultural Research m1326207 197,Agricultural Laws and Regulations m1327358 171

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Agricultural Research, Extension and
            Training Project (ARETP) in Sudan. The Agricultural
            Research, Extension and Training Project (ARETP) was well
            conceived and its objectives were attainable within the
            country context; it focused on the "core"
            activities necessary to: (a) consolidate the achievements of
            previous Bank interventions; and (b) encourage the
            development potential of Sudan's agriculture sector.
            ARETP, thus, aimed to improve the performance of the
            irrigated subsector through the introduction of improved and
            sustainable management practices, supported by strengthened
            and reorganized research and extension services, and
            comprehensive training at all staff levels. The importance
            of strengthening the technological base to provide relevant
            extension messages aimed at achieving immediate results and
            benefits was stressed. The key findings and lessons of ARETP
            were as follows: (i)short overseas visits to successful
            research/ extension projects helped develop managerial
            commitment to the T&V approach, and may have been more
            beneficial than formal training in methodologies; (ii) a
            notable achievement of ARETP was the significant level of
            effective collaboration with several IARCS; (iii) the
            project's extension component, was established
            gradually, on the basis of the delivery capacity of the
            extension service. Only those fieldinspectors who
            demonstrated a commitment to the system were transferred to
            the extension service.Additionally, the extension system was
            designed to be flexible. Messages were transmitted only
            whentheir technical content had been fully tested; thus,
            effective research/extension linkage was developed.
            Extension was successfully carried out through informal
            farmer groups, which promoted a wider sense of ownership and
            acceptability; (iv) another notable achievement, relates to
            the attempts at cOst recovery/sharing by project
            beneficiaries (APCs and farmers), at New Halfa and Rahad;
            (v) the prolilnms arising in ARETP's implementation
            should have been analyzed and prompt corrective action
            wakento address these issues; and (vi) in retrospect, a
            general but crucial lesson relates to the combinled impact
            of Bank-assisted agricultural research projects, focusing on
            the irrigated sub-sector.
